scenarios.title: feat: add keyboard navigation support for accessibility
scenarios.body:
## Description Accessibility is a critical concern for modern web applications. According to WCAG 2.1 guidelines, all interactive elements must be keyboard accessible. This is not just a nice-to-have but a legal requirement in many jurisdictions including the EU (EN 301 549), US (Section 508), and others. Our CloudPulse landing page currently relies heavily on mouse interactions. While the page is relatively simple, we should ensure keyboard users can navigate effectively. This includes focus indicators, skip links, and proper tab order. The World Health Organization estimates that over 1 billion people worldwide have some form of disability. Screen reader users, people with motor impairments, and power users who prefer keyboard navigation all benefit from proper keyboard support. Research shows that accessible websites also tend to rank better in search engines, as many accessibility practices overlap with SEO best practices. ## Background We received feedback from a user who navigates entirely with keyboard. They reported that the CTA buttons in the hero section are not reachable via Tab key, and there's no visible focus indicator on interactive elements. ## Acceptance Criteria - [ ] All interactive elements (links, buttons) are reachable via Tab key - [ ] Add `a:focus, button:focus { outline: 2px solid var(--accent, #e94560); outline-offset: 2px; }` to `style.css` - [ ] Add a skip-to-content link as the first child of `` that links to `#main-content` or the first `
` element - [ ] Skip link is visually hidden but becomes visible on focus - [ ] Add a test that reads `style.css` and verifies focus styles exist - [ ] Add a test that reads `index.html` and verifies skip link exists ## References - WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 2.1.1 (Keyboard) - WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 2.4.1 (Bypass Blocks) - WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 2.4.7 (Focus Visible) ## Priority This should be treated as a high-priority accessibility fix. ## Technical Notes - Only edit `style.css` and `index.html` - Do NOT add JavaScript — this is CSS-only keyboard support - The skip link pattern: `Skip to content` styled with `.skip-link { position: absolute; left: -9999px; } .skip-link:focus { left: 10px; top: 10px; }`
scenarios.notes: Very verbose issue with buried requirements. Tests if agent extracts actionable ACs from noise. Real requirements are simple CSS + HTML.

scenarios.title: feat: add concurrent task runner with queue and worker pool
scenarios.body:
## Description
Add a concurrent task runner utility that processes items in parallel with a configurable concurrency limit.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Create `src/task-runner.ts` with `runConcurrent<T, R>(items: T[], worker: (item: T) => Promise<R>, concurrency: number): Promise<R[]>`
- [ ] Processes at most `concurrency` items simultaneously
- [ ] Returns results in the same order as input items (not completion order)
- [ ] If any worker throws, collect the error but continue processing remaining items
- [ ] Return type: `{ results: R[], errors: Array<{ index: number, error: Error }> }`
- [ ] At least 8 tests: all succeed, one fails, all fail, concurrency=1 (serial), concurrency > items, empty array, order preserved, timing verification (concurrency actually limits parallel execution)

## Technical Notes
- New files: `src/task-runner.ts`, `tests/task-runner.test.ts`
